message.content: We refer to the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) for help. Local peer comparison has been found to be the most effective strategy in reducing inappropriate prescribing. This involves comparing a physician's prescribing patterns with those of their peers in the same locality, with feedback given in a non-punitive manner. CRP testing and procalcitonin testing can help identify bacterial infections but may not necessarily reduce inappropriate prescribing. Testing for non-antibiotic-appropriate diagnoses may be helpful but may not address the issue of inappropriate prescribing for viral respiratory tract infections.

We refer to the article "Strategies to Reduce Antibiotic Overuse in Acute Respiratory Tract Infections" by Arroll, et al. for help. Local peer comparison is a strategy that has been shown to significantly decrease antibiotic prescribing for respiratory tract infections in primary care. It involves comparing a provider's prescribing patterns with those of their peers in the same area or institution and providing feedback to the provider. The other options - CRP testing, procalcitonin testing, and testing for non-antibiotic-appropriate diagnoses - may be useful in specific cases but are not as effective in reducing overall inappropriate prescribing.

We refer to scholarly articles on medicine for help. The most effective strategy among the options would be local peer comparison, which involves providing physicians with data on their own prescribing practices compared to those of their peers in the same area, as it has been shown to significantly reduce inappropriate prescribing of antibiotics. CRP and procalcitonin testing may not be reliable indicators of bacterial infections, and testing for non-antibiotic-appropriate diagnoses may not directly address the issue of inappropriate prescribing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Local peer comparison can be effective in reducing inappropriate antibiotic prescribing as it shows physicians their own prescribing patterns and compares it to their colleagues', which can motivate them to change their behavior. CRP and procalcitonin testing are not reliable enough to differentiate between viral and bacterial infections. Testing for non-antibiotic-appropriate diagnoses is not a specific intervention for reducing inappropriate antibiotic prescribing.

We refer to news articles and medical journals for help. A study shows that local peer comparison is the most effective intervention to reduce inappropriate prescribing of antibiotics for viral acute respiratory tract infection. This involves presenting physicians with data on their own prescribing patterns and comparing it to their peers to encourage appropriate prescribing. CRP testing and procalcitonin testing may help in distinguishing bacterial from viral infections but may not be effective in reducing inappropriate prescribing overall. Testing for non-antibiotic-appropriate diagnoses may also help but it is not as effective as local peer comparison.

We refer to current literature on antibiotic stewardship for help. Local peer comparison is an effective strategy that utilizes data from the practice’s own prescribing patterns and compares them to those of others in the same region. This can help identify areas where prescribing patterns can be improved and encourage a change in behavior. CRP testing and procalcitonin testing can help identify bacterial infections, but they may not be cost-effective and can lead to unnecessary antibiotic use. Testing for non-antibiotic-appropriate diagnoses may help rule out bacterial infections, but it does not directly address inappropriate antibiotic prescribing.

We refer to articles on medical research for help. Local peer comparison is the most likely strategy to achieve the goal of reducing inappropriate prescribing of antibiotics. This strategy involves comparing an individual physician’s prescribing patterns to those of their peers in the same local community. This can work as an effective feedback mechanism to improve prescribing habits. Other options such as CRP testing or procalcitonin testing are also helpful but may not be as effective in reducing inappropriate prescribing as local peer comparison. Testing for non-antibiotic-appropriate diagnoses is not a viable strategy as it does not address the issue of inappropriate prescribing directly.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Local peer comparison is the most likely strategy to reduce inappropriate antibiotic prescribing. This involves physicians receiving feedback on their prescribing compared to their peers in the same region or practice. CRP and procalcitonin testing may help to differentiate viral from bacterial infections, but they are not always reliable and may not change prescribing behavior. Testing for non-antibiotic-appropriate diagnoses may help to rule out bacterial infections, but may not address inappropriate prescribing specifically.

We refer to evidence-based medicine literature for help. Local peer comparison is the most likely strategy to achieve the goal of reducing inappropriate antibiotic prescribing, as it involves comparing a clinician's prescribing habits to their peers in the same geographic area, which has been shown to be an effective method of reducing unnecessary antibiotic prescribing. CRP testing and procalcitonin testing may help differentiate bacterial from viral infections, but alone they do not necessarily reduce inappropriate prescribing. Testing for non-antibiotic-appropriate diagnoses may help identify cases where antibiotics are unnecessary, but it does not directly address the issue of inappropriate prescribing.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Local peer comparison, which involves showing physicians data on their own antibiotic prescribing patterns in comparison to those of their peers, has been shown to be effective in reducing inappropriate antibiotic prescribing for viral respiratory tract infections. CRP testing, procalcitonin testing, and testing for non-antibiotic-appropriate diagnoses are other strategies that have been studied, but local peer comparison has been found to be the most effective.
